so this is part one is the model behaving the same way for everybody

make sure Healthcare AI is fair and then last I'll touch on how do we
make sure that Healthcare AI is reliable now that also has two parts
sometimes it manifests as explainability or transparency or interpretability and
those are the different words that are being used um I broke the I break this down into three uh categories so there is this
notion of the engineering interpretability in the sense that
what is the mechanics of how a model produced the output like the underlying
mathematical formulation and you know what are the weights being transmitted and how what are the features or the
data elements the model is relying on that's the engineering interpretation of real interpretability I'm sorry
and knowing that gives us some information to decide is this
model reliable but then there's two other aspects to it there's the causal nature of
interpretability in the sense that why did a certain input produce the
output so I'll give an example you can have a model an algorithm that you train on
patient information which can come up with a silly sounding conclusion that says those men who have
white hair or are bald have a high risk of a heart attack
that's a true Association from an engineering standpoint I can
even explain the weights behind that particular uh observation
but from a causal sense Whitehead have very little to do with the with the uh getting a heart attack
and it's it's just a confounding a confounded finding just happens that
older age you tend to have white hair or you might have you might be bald and at that point your risk of heart attack is
higher so from a causal interpretation standpoint that model is completely
useless even though it's risk estimate might actually be fairly accurate
in another situation we have this thing called the pooled cohort equation that looks at blood pressure cholesterol
diabetes and so on in order to produce the estimate of having a heart attack in
that case the interpretation of that is causally valid and then the third thing is often a
clinician would ask for interpretability in order to make the decision that can I
trust this particular AI this algorithm or this model and so it's a surrogate for
trust now trust can be established by other means you know if we if we look at
the 4900 or so FDA approved drugs a lot of them we don't have the faintest
idea how they work but we have established that they do work by performing a prospective
randomized control trial so when we think about how to ensure that Healthcare AI is reliable we have
to unpack whether are we talking about the engineering interpretation are we ex are we requesting a causal
Association or a causal finding because that is necessary if you want to take some mitigating action in the example
we're using painting somebody's hair black that's not going to change their heart attack risk but lowering their cholesterol certainly will and so in
that case it does matter you know what is the causal mechanism and then if the need is to establish
trust uh there are some very interesting findings from Microsoft research that
sometimes an explanation of providing explanation leads to higher than
necessary trust and the and the users fail to spot the mistakes of the model
it's an elegant series of experiments where they've shown that if you're shown a model to predict the price of an
apartment and then you're given the engineering explanation you will fail to
spot the mistake of a model trying to price an apartment which is like 700 square feet and has four bedrooms and
five bathrooms which is like logically impossible uh but because the model is
explainable people will tend to trust it so there's some goofy things that can happen if we don't unpack these three
Notions of reliability and then there's a second at part to
reliability which is is the decision making done being done based on the
model getting us the outcomes we want so for example
on the x-axis here we have some percentage of the population receiving intervention let's say prescribing
statins in the case of a heart attack risk and on the y-axis the number of outcomes
desirable outcomes uh obtained for example preventing a heart attack
if we do things at random which is here 50 of the people will get a Statin and

this line which is called the burrito Frontier where we say all right what if our AI was
